title: 114_hr4943
content: The Act may be cited as the "Tribal Tax and Investment Reform Act of 2016". The Congress recognizes the unique relationship between the United States and Indian tribes, acknowledging tribes' authority to provide programs and services, develop economies, and maintain infrastructure on reservation lands. Federal laws and treaties affirm tribes' governmental status, allowing them to tax, issue bonds, and receive tax exemptions. Tax parity for tribal governments aligns with their sovereignty and addresses historic capital access challenges. Congress affirms the United States government-to-government relationship with Indian tribes, recognizing their historic disadvantages in accessing capital and unfair tax treatment in the Internal Revenue Code. The text chunk "SEC. 3. TREATMENT OF INDIAN TRIBES AS STATES WITH RESPECT TO BOND ISSUANCE" is about recognizing Indian tribes as states for bond issuance purposes. The text chunk amends subsection (c) of section 7871 of the Internal Revenue Code to establish special rules for tax-exempt bonds issued by Indian tribal governments. It includes provisions for establishing a national bond volume cap based on tribal population estimates and allocating this cap among tribal governments seeking an allocation. The text chunk amends section 7871 of the Internal Revenue Code by allocating a national bond volume cap among Indian tribal governments. It also repeals certain requirements and specifies effective dates for these changes. SEC. 4. Treatment of pension and employee benefit plans maintained by tribal governments. Amendments to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 include expanding the definition of qualified public safety employee to include Indian tribes and updating the definition of governmental plan to encompass plans established by Indian tribal governments or entities. Amendments to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 include expanding the definition of qualified public safety employee to include Indian tribes and updating the definition of governmental plan to encompass plans established by Indian tribal governments or entities. This includes plans maintained by an Indian tribal government, agency, instrumentality, or subdivision, as well as entities wholly owned or controlled by them. Additionally, the amendments include provisions for domestic relations orders and exempt governmental deferred compensation plans, specifically for Indian tribal governments or subdivisions. Plans established before the enactment date and maintained by Indian tribal governments are grandfathered under certain conditions. The amendments made by this section shall apply to years beginning after the date of the enactment of this Act. SEC. 5. Treatment of tribal foundations and charities like charities funded and controlled by other governmental funders and sponsors. The amendment expands the definition of "governmental unit" to include Indian tribal governments and related entities for tax purposes. This change also applies to supporting organizations and is effective for taxable years after the enactment of the Act. SEC. 6. IMPROVING TRIBAL CHILD SUPPORT ENFORCEMENT AGENCIES' ACCESS TO FEDERAL PARENT LOCATOR SERVICE AND TAX REFUND OFFSETS. The Social Security Act is amended to grant access to the Federal Parent Locator Service to Indian tribes or tribal organizations eligible for a grant under section 455(f). Additionally, Indian tribes or tribal organizations eligible for a grant under section 455(f) are now subject to the same rules regarding the collection of past-due child support from federal tax refunds as states with approved plans. The requirement to distribute amounts in accordance with section 457 applies to Indian tribes or tribal organizations eligible for a grant under section 455(f) in the same way it applies to states with approved plans. An amendment to the Internal Revenue Code includes Indian tribes or tribal organizations in references to states for tax refund purposes. SEC. 7. Amends the Internal Revenue Code to include Indian tribal governments in determining special needs for the adoption credit. Effective for taxable years after enactment of the Act.
